derivation.yuyuan_name: early 19th cent.: of unknown origin. Early use was as a noun denoting a horse of little value, later applied to a poor white in some Southern states of the US, hence 'shabby, cheap, in bad taste' (mid 19th cent.)

entry.tran: 做工粗糙的;劣质的;俗气的
entry.def: If you describe something as tacky, you dislike it because it is cheap and badly made or vulgar.

example.ex: ...a woman in a fake leopard-skin coat and tacky red sunglasses...
example.tran: 身穿假豹皮大衣、戴着俗气的大红色太阳镜的女人

example.ex: The whole thing is dreadfully tacky.

entry.def: If something such as paint or glue is tacky, it is slightly sticky and not yet dry.

example.ex: Test to see if the finish is tacky, and if it is, leave it to harden.
example.tran: 看看最后一道漆干了没有，要是没干，就先让它干透。

means.word_mean: 1. (of a glutinous liquid such as paint) not completely dried and slightly sticky to the touch;

auth_sentence.content: It's bad-quality and it looks tacky and cluttered.

auth_sentence.content: Everyone thought it was tacky, but I liked it.
auth_sentence.res_content: Everyone thought it was tacky, but I liked it.

means.word_mean: 粘而未干的;(漆等)尚未干透的

sentences.en: The paint on the door is still tacky.
sentences.cn: 门上的油漆还没有干透。

means.word_mean: 俗气的；俗不可耐的；不文雅的

sentences.en: She looks really tacky in that dress.
sentences.cn: 她穿那件衣服看起来俗不可耐。
